SEARCH
Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog

Class ProgressionSearch

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.search.Search<CompiledAction>
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.ProgressionSearch
All Implemented Interfaces:
Worker.Getter<Result<CompiledAction>>
Direct Known Subclasses:
ExplanationFirstSearch, GoalFirstSearch
public class ProgressionSearch extends Search<CompiledAction>
A progression search is a forward search through the space of states that starts as a specified initial state and runs until its finds a solution plan which increases the author's utility to or above a specified goal value and for which every action in the plan makes sense based on the beliefs and intentions of the characters who take that action.

A progression search iteratively generates and visits search nodes, which are states defined by the sequence of actions (a plan) taken to reach that state. Each time an action is added to a plan, that action must be explained for each of its consenting characters. A branch is created for each consenting character by calculating the state that character believes to be that case after taking the action. This state forms the root of a smaller search that takes place within the larger search to improve that character's utility.

In other words, a progression search can be thought of as many smaller searches, each with its own root, that tries to improve the utility for one character. The primary search starts in the problem's initial state and tries to improve the author's utility. Each time an action needs to be explained for a character, a new search starts, rooted in the state that character believes to be the case after taking the action and aiming to improve that character's utility. When characters anticipate the actions of other characters, new searches start, and so on.

A progression search is primarily defined by four things:

  • The search space used to model states.
  • The search method, which constrains the order in which states are visited.
  • A cost function which calculates the work done to construct a plan so far.
  • A heuristic function which estimates the remaining work still neded to make a plan into a solution.
By default, a progression search visits states in a best first order, which means the next node to be visited is the one with the lowest sum of its cost and heuristic. See compare(SearchNode, SearchNode) for more details on the order in which states are visited.
Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Field Details

    • problem

      public final CompiledProblem problem
      The problem this search is solving

    • cost

      public final ProgressionCost cost
      A function to measure the cost of a plan so far

    • heuristic

      public final ProgressionCost heuristic
      A function to estimate the cost to complete a plan

    • explanationPruning

      public final boolean explanationPruning
      Whether or not this search will use explanation pruning, which means that a node will not be visited if its root is already explained. In other words, explanation pruning means that once one explanation for an action has been found, that branch of the search stops. Explanation pruning can improve the speed of the overall search, but may sometimes be undesirable if the search is meant to find more than one explanation for some actions.

    • actions

      protected final EventTree<CompiledAction> actions
      An event tree of actions for efficiently detecting which actions apply in a state

    • space

      protected final ProgressionSpace<?> space
      A underlying model of states used in the search

    • queue

      protected final PriorityQueue<edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<?>> queue
      A min priority queue of search nodes that defines the order in which states are visited

  • Constructor Details

    • ProgressionSearch

      public ProgressionSearch(CompiledProblem problem, ProgressionCost cost, ProgressionCost heuristic, EventTree<CompiledAction> actions, ProgressionSpace<N> space, long searchLimit, long spaceLimit, long timeLimit, int authorTemporalLimit, int characterTemporalLimit, int epistemicLimit, boolean explanationPruning)
      Constructs a new progression search.
      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      problem - the compiled problem to be solved
      cost - a function to measure the cost of a plan so far
      heuristic - a function to estimate the cost of making a plan into a solution
      actions - an event tree of all actions that can be taken during search
      space - the model of states that will be searched
      searchLimit - the max number of nodes that can be visited
      spaceLimit - the max number of nodes that can be generated
      timeLimit - the max number of milliseconds a search can take
      authorTemporalLimit - the max number of actions in the main plan
      characterTemporalLimit - the max number of actions a character can imagine when trying to explain its actions
      epistemicLimit - the max depth in a character's theory of mind to search
      explanationPruning - whether the search should stop exploring a branch once its root has been explained

    • getStart

      public State getStart()
      Description copied from class: Search
      Returns the initial state of the world from which a solution plan must be executable. Unless changed by the Search.setStart(State) method, the initial state should be the one defined by the planning problem.
      Specified by:

    • setStart

      public void setStart(State state)
      Description copied from class: Search
      Sets the initial state of the world from which a solution plan must be executable. This method resets this search object, meaning it should discard its internal state, should start over (from the newly set initial state) the next time Search.get(Status) is called, and may reset counters such as the number of nodes visited.
      Specified by:
      setStart in class Search<CompiledAction>
      Parameters:
      state - the new initial state of the world before planning begins

    • run

      protected void run(Progress<CompiledAction> progress, Worker.Status status)
      Description copied from class: Search
      This method searches for the next solution, resuming where the previous call left off (unless Search.setStart(State) has been called to reset the search). A progress object is provided to track whether a search has finished and to count values such as nodes visited and generated (since methods like Search.getVisited() track total nodes visited). A status object should be updated periodically to reflect this method's progress.
      Specified by:
      run in class Search<CompiledAction>
      Parameters:
      progress - a progress object used to track the nodes visited, nodes generated, and whether a suitable solution has been found by this search
      status - a status to update while the search runs

    • setStatus

      protected void setStatus(Worker.Status status, Progress<CompiledAction> progress)
      Sets the message and parameters of the status that will be updated during the search. This method will be called once at the beginning of a new search, and the status will be periodically updated via updateStatus(Status, Progress).
      Parameters:
      status - the status object whose message and parameters will be set
      progress - the progress object for the search that is just starting

    • updateStatus

      protected void updateStatus(Worker.Status status, Progress<CompiledAction> progress)
      Updates the status during a search. This method will be called after visiting each node during the search, but only after setStatus(Status, Progress) has been called once for this search.
      Parameters:
      status - the status object to update
      progress - the progress object for the current search

    • prune

      protected <N> boolean prune(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node)
      Determines whether a search node should be pruned (that is, not visited). This method is called before visit(SearchNode), and it it returns true, the node will not be visited.

      By default, this method returns true only when explanation pruning is on, the node's epistemic depth is greater than 0, and the given node's root is explained.

      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      node - the search node that is about to be visited if it is not pruned
      Returns:
      true if the search node should be pruned (that is, not visited), or false if the node should be visited

    • visit

      protected <N> boolean visit(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node)
      Performs one iteration of the search on the given search node. One iteration usually means removing one node from the queue, visiting that node, and possibly adding more nodes to the queue. If this method returns true, the number of visited nodes will be incremented by one, otherwise it will not be incremented.

      By default, this method simply calls expand(SearchNode) with the same node and returns true.

      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      node - the search node to be visited
      Returns:
      true if the number of visited nodes should be incremented, false otherwise

    • expand

      protected <N> void expand(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node)
      Finds all relevant actions that can be taken in a given search node's state and calls expand(SearchNode, CompiledAction) for the node and each action. There are several criteria for a relevant action:
      • A relevant action's precondition must evaluate to true in the state represented by the given search node.
      • Actions which have no consenting characters can only be taken when the node's epistemic depth is 0 (in other words, actions taken by no character can only be chosen by the author).
      • If the node's temporal depth is greater than or equal to the search's temporal limit (which is the author temporal limit when epistemic depth is 0, or the character temporal limit when epistemic depth is greater than 0), no actions are relevant, because taking any action would expand the search space past its temporal limit.
      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      node - the search node whose relevant actions will be considered

    • expand

      protected <N> boolean expand(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> parent, CompiledAction action)
      This method is called for each action that is relevant to the state represented by a given search node. See expand(SearchNode) for a description of when actions are relevant.

      By default, this method will generate a child for the given node using the given action and call explain(SearchNode), which generates a branch for each of the action's consenting characters. The child and all branches will only be added to the queue if all of them can be added to the queue. In other words, if push(SearchNode) returns false for the child or any branch, neither the child nor any of its branches will be added to the queue.

      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      parent - the search node to which the action is relevant
      action - the relevant action
      Returns:
      true if the child generated for that action was successfully added to the search queue, or false if nothing was added to the queue

    • explain

      protected <N> boolean explain(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> trunk)
      Generates a branch for each consenting character of the action that led to the given search node and adds them to the search queue. The branches will only be added if all of them can be added; in other words, if push(SearchNode) fails for any branch, none of the branches will be added.
      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      trunk - a search node representing the state after taking the action that will be explained
      Returns:
      true if all branches were successfully added to the search queue, or false if any branch does not exist or could not be added

    • push

      protected <N> boolean push(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node)
      Adds a search node to the search queue. This method returns true if the node was added successfully or false if the node was not added.

      By default, this method returns false if the node's epistemic depth exceeds the search's epistemic limit. It also calculates the cost and heuristic values for the search node and sets them. If either cost is positive infinity, this method returns false. Otherwise, this method adds the node to the queue and returns true.

      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      node - the node to be added to the queue
      Returns:
      true if the node was added to the queue; false if the node was not added

    • compare

      protected <N> double compare(edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node1, edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.prog.SearchNode<N> node2)
      Defines the priority in which search nodes should be visited. This method follows the contract of Comparator.compare(Object, Object), except that it returns a double instead of an int. In other words, this method should return a negative number if the first node should be visited before the second node, a positive number if the second node should be visited before the first, or 0 if the order does not matter.

      By default, this method prioritizes nodes in this order:

      • The node with the lowest cost plus heuristic value is first.
      • In case of a tie, the node with the lowest heuristic value is first.
      • In case of a further tie, the node with the lowest epistemic depth is first.
      • In case of a further tie, the root for both nodes are compared.
      • In case of a further tie, the node objects of both nodes are compared.
      Type Parameters:
      N - the type of object used to represent a node in the search space
      Parameters:
      node1 - the first node to be compared
      node2 - the second node to be compared
      Returns:
      a negative double, zero, or a positive double as the first node is higher priority, the same priority, or lower priority than the second node
